intro_text.text: The day was disrupted by the noise that rules the world. I was celebrating with friends: Mark, the ambitious nursery assistant; Alex, the jokester boxer; Derick, the quiet architect; and Dom, the chaotic journalist.
Alex: AYYYEE! They won 5:2! Ha-ha, shameful, Zack?
Tom: Who thought that? Still… 15 UCL.
Alex: Don’t remind me of last UCL. Wake up, Zack!
Derick: Guys, they win and lose daily. What about life after uni?
Said: Bro, let me eat first. Honestly? I haven’t decided. World’s chaotic.
Me: Let’s drop it. Raise a glass to friendship!
Tom: Agree!
We drank green tea. TV barked with noise. Masked figures announced humanity’s wipeout.
Hello, humanity! We’re happy to announce your end. You’ve rotted — no fairness, only drama.
Alex: Get rid of that clown on screen.
Derick: Alex… tss.
Screen darkened. World changed forever. Ten hours left. Nuclear warheads ready.
We thank insiders. Nations under control: Russia, China, USA, etc.
Alex: Nice joke, lol.
Tom: Someone’s calling… What the hell?
Phones buzzed with government alerts: imminent death, nuclear launches. Authorities working to disable.
Silence followed, then screams from every corner. Chaos erupted.
The screams outside didn’t stop. They trembled in the walls like a living echo.
Alex grabbed my arm. 'Bro… we need to get ready. We can’t stay here.'
My hands were shaking. How do you prepare for the end of the world?
Tom: 'We need essentials. Passport. Food. Anything we can carry.'
Derick checked the hallway. 'We don’t have long. Grab what you can.'
I rushed to the kitchen — my mind blank, my body running on instinct.
Alex: 'Bro, hurry! We need to be out in minutes!'
Dom: 'Guys, I heard glass break upstairs… people are losing it!'
I had one mission: find my passport, knife, and enough food to survive one day.
Drawers slammed, shelves rattled — everything mattered now.
The street looked like another world — smoke, running silhouettes, broken voices.
A man bumped into me so hard I almost fell. His eyes were swallowed by fear.
Dom: 'This is insane… I’ve never seen humans act like this.'
Tom: 'Keep moving! Parking lot is two blocks away!'
Then I saw her — a woman lying near the wall, barely conscious.
Her arm was twisted unnaturally. Bruises covered her face.
Sara: 'P-please… help me… my husband… he’s looking for me…'
Alex whispered: 'Bro, we don’t have time. She’s done.'
Derick: 'Shut up, Alex. He decides.'
The world froze. One path meant saving her. The other — saving us.
The parking lot was a graveyard of abandoned cars and dropped belongings.
We reached our car. Dust covered the windows — I hadn’t touched it in months.
Tom: 'Try it. Just try to start it.'
I turned the key. Nothing. Not even a cough.
Alex: 'Bro… we’re screwed. Starter’s dead.'
Dom: 'Maybe if we push it? Try rolling?'
We pushed with all our strength. The car rolled, choked, and died again.
Alex: 'Okay. I know what's wrong. But we need a replacement part.'
Derick: 'Where do we find it?'
Alex: 'There’s a shop ten minutes away… if it’s still there.'
The shop was silent — unnervingly silent. Shelves still full, untouched by panic.
An older man stood at the counter — tired eyes, silver hair.
Old Man: 'You boys need something?'
Alex: 'Starter module. Please.'
Old Man sighed. 'Take it. Take anything… I’ve lived long enough.'
Then the door slammed open with violent force.
Armed men rushed inside — shouting, kicking shelves, grabbing whatever they wanted.
Bandit: 'Hands up! No hero shit!'
Tom: 'Bro— hide! NOW!'
The store turned into a maze — shelves, crates, shadows, panic.
My heart punched my ribs like it wanted out of my body.
If I hid — we had a chance. If I failed — everything was gone.
I held my breath behind the shelf, motionless. One wrong sound would cost us everything.
Footsteps echoed between the aisles — slow, searching, predatory.
Dom covered his mouth to keep from breathing too loudly.
Alex peeked through a crack. He whispered: 'Bro… one of them is coming our way.'
Suddenly, a loud crash distracted the gunmen. A shelf collapsed near the front of the store.
Derick: 'Now. MOVE.'
We sprinted through the back exit, carrying the stolen starter module.
Our lungs burned, but the parking lot was close. If we made it — we lived.
I tried to hide — but it was too late.
A hand grabbed my shoulder and slammed me against the shelf.
Bandit: 'Thought you could play hero?'
Dom shouted, but another gunman pointed a pistol at him.
They ripped the car keys from Alex's pocket.
Bandit Leader: 'You're coming with us. Show us the car.'
Alex looked at me — terrified but trying to smile. 'Bro… it's okay. Just survive.'
They dragged him away. His voice slowly faded into the distance.
We had nothing. No car. No supplies. And Alex… gone.
The car rolled through the ruins of the city, headlights cutting through smoke.
Tom gripped the wheel with trembling hands.
Zack tapped his knee nervously — a steady beat of fear.
Most of the apps on my phone refused to load.
Every navigation app displayed the same message: 'Service unavailable.'
Tom: 'Bro, we can’t drive blindly. Find SOMETHING.'
I scrolled through my phone — screenshots, old projects, offline files.
Somewhere in this digital graveyard, a map had to exist.
Tom killed the engine. Rain dripped softly onto the metal roof.
The world outside was an empty field — silent, endless, unsettling.
Zack stepped out first, his breath forming pale clouds.
Dom groaned. 'Bro… I’m freezing already.'
Objectives appeared in my mind like survival instincts whispering commands.
Make fire. Make water. Stay alive.
Hours later, after collapsing near the dying flames — something touched the car door.
A slow, scraping, deliberate sound.
I turned my head — glowing eyes surrounded us.
Morning arrived with a pale, colourless light over the empty field.
Dom stared at the car. 'We need fuel. This tank is bone-dry.'
The petrol station looked abandoned — but not dead.
The metal sign creaked as the wind pushed it back and forth.
I grabbed an empty container and approached the pump.
One mistake could destroy the engine forever.
Three minutes. That was all the time we had before something went wrong.
And something DID go wrong.
A black car rolled into the station. Five men stepped out.
The fog thickened until the headlights barely pierced the darkness.
Suddenly, the road ended. We arrived in a ghost town near a desolate beach.
Said panic rose. 'This is the WRONG direction! We shouldn't be here!'
Dom remained composed. 'We don't know anything anymore. Let's look around.'
We realized we needed to signal someone, but we had no flare gun.
The wind sliced through our jackets. We needed to make a signal.
We had to reach 100 Signal Points before the cold took us.
We could shout, burn the car, or shoot into the sky.
After a desperate struggle, a beam of light cut through the fog.
A massive ship emerged from the darkness.
The ship was close, but Derick whispered, 'I... can't swim.'
Dom pulled out his gun. 'Someone has to stay behind. We can't carry everyone.'
He pointed the gun at Said.
I had to choose: Sacrifice myself and swim, or let the group crumble.
We were pulled aboard the rescue boat. Dom threw his gun into the sea.
Dom: 'I lost control... it was survival instinct.'
On the main deck, the crew found a gun in Said's backpack.
They threw Said overboard. Dom watched. Dead stare.
The game ended not with a win, but with moral devastation.
